title: Will you allow Muslims on Hindu boards? Supreme Court questions Waqf composition
summary: The Supreme Court questioned the religious composition of Waqf boards during a hearing on the Waqf Amendment Act. Chief Justice Khanna challenged the inclusion of non-Muslim members by asking if Muslims would similarly be allowed on Hindu endowment boards. The Court provided interim relief and clarified that all Waqf board members must be Muslim, except ex-officio members.
content:
The Supreme Court on Wednesday questioned the religious composition of Waqf board during a hearing on the constitutional validity of the Waqf (Amendment) Act, 2025. The inclusion of non-Muslim members in the Waqf board is one of the main points of contention, with petitioners arguing that the move dilutes the freedom of Muslims to manage their own religion.

Chief Justice of India Sanjiv Khanna asked Solicitor General Tushar Mehta, "Are you saying that from now on you will allow Muslims to be part of Hindu endowment boards? Say it openly."

The Chief Justice pointed out that as per the Act, eight members of the board are Muslims, and possibly only two are not. The Solicitor General's suggestion that "this bench also cannot hear the case" drew a strong rebuke from the Court.

The Court clarified that all Waqf board members must be Muslim, except ex-officio members. Justice Viswanathan noted practical issues such as ingress and egress in mosques, where familiarity with the premises might be relevant.

Providing interim relief, the Court stated that properties declared as Waqf by courts should not be de-notified during the proceedings. The hearing will continue with the three-judge bench comprising CJI Khanna, Justice Sanjay Kumar, and Justice KV Viswanathan.

content.content:
Listen to Story

The Supreme Court on Wednesday questioned the religious composition of Waqf board during a hearing on the constitutional validity of the Waqf (Amendment) Act, 2025. Theinclusion of non-Muslim members in the Waqf boardis one of the main points of contention, with petitioners arguing that the move dilutes the freedom of Muslims to manage their own religion.

Chief Justice of India Sanjiv Khanna asked Solicitor General Tushar Mehta, “Are you saying that from now on you will allow Muslims to be part of Hindu endowment boards? Say it openly.”

The remark came as the bench questioned why non-Muslims could not be part of Waqf advisory panels if the reverse was also not allowed.

The Chief Justice pointed out that as per the Act, eight members of the board are Muslims, and possibly only two are not. “Why not have Muslims also on the advisory board of Hindu endowments then?” he said.

The Solicitor General then suggested that by the same logic “this bench also cannot hear the case”.

The remark drew a fiery response from the Supreme Court bench.

"What! When we sit over here. We lose our religion. For us both sides are the same. How can you compare it with the judges?" the Chief Justice said.

Justice Viswanathan also noted that there were practical issues such as ingress and outgress in mosques, which is why familiarity with the premises might be relevant. The SG responded that such checks could be conducted by the Charity Commissioner.

The three-judge bench comprising CJI Khanna, Justice Sanjay Kumar, and Justice KV Viswanathan will continue the hearing tomorrow.ABOUT WAQF HEARING IN COURT

The Supreme Court on Wednesdayheard a batch of petitionschallenging the constitutional validity of the Waqf (Amendment) Act. The bench, led by Chief Justice Sanjiv Khanna, flagged concerns over the practicality of undoing waqf by user, especially for centuries-old masjids without registered sale deeds. The Court also questioned the composition of Waqf boards, which would include non-Muslim members following the amendment of Act.

Providing interim relief, the Court said that properties declared as Waqf by courts should not be de-notified during the proceedings. It also stayed the provision that would prevent properties from being treated as Waqf while under investigation by the District Collector. The Court clarified that all Waqf board members must be Muslim, except ex-officio members. The hearing will continue tomorrow at 2 pm.Published By:Anuja JhaPublished On:Apr 16, 2025Tune InMust Watch
